Summary: All seventeen aboard were Chinese nationals.
Stalled at low altitiude on approach to land

Airline/Op: Maddux Airlines / Military - U.S.Army Air Force
Bremerton-Seattle Air Taxi / Gorst Air Lines

Summary: While en route to Chicago, the aircraft was destroyed by an explosive device placed in the cargo hold, consisting of nitro-glycerin and attached to a timing device. This was the first proven case of sabotage in the history of commercial aviation.
Plunged to the ground thirty minutes after leaving Fort Worth. Tried to return to Dallas airport due to inclement weather.

Airline/Op: North Sea Aerial and General Transport

Summary: Forced to ditch into the sea due to bad weather. One wing broke off due to high waves and 8 passengers hung on to the remaining wing until rescued.
Bronislaw Hubermann, celibrated Polish violinist was sightly injured.
Hit the ground prematurely while attempting to land.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S. Navy / Military - U.S. Navy

Summary: Flew into a hillside soon after takeoff from Kisumu. The ship was named 'Amalthea.'
The plane was carrying Hungarian journalists.
Missing. One postal bag found in a glacier.
One Swedish passenger was killed when the plane was attacked by German fighters. The plane was able to land safely in Amsterdam.
Midair collisioin with a private plane.

Airline/Op: Great Western and Southern Air Lines

Summary: Midair collision over the Gulf of Mexico while flying in formation. Eleven killed on each plane.
Cashed into trees shortly after taking off.
Stalled when it was making a descending turn during a parachute exercise.
A navigational error caused the cargo plane to strike a mountain.
Flew into a hill shortly after talking off from Ward's Strip operated by Qantas for Allied Directorate of Air Transport.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S. Army Air Forces / Military - U.S. Army Air Forces

Summary: The cargo plane flew into a mountain
The plane missing and never found.

The plane discintigrated in mid-aid. The jack pad had been removed from the right wing root. This left 4 large holes directly under the fuel tanks and directly in line with the exhaust. When the throttles were cut to descend, the flame only went as far back as the holes. There the flames went up around the fuel tank, igniting the fumes and blew the wing off.
Diverted to Kweilin after Chunking was below minimums. After holding over Kweilin for 3 hours, the aircraft ran out of gas, hit mountain and was demolished.
As the aircraft approached land, it began a climb but was not able to gain sufficient altitude to clear a cloud shrouded cliff.

Airline/Op: Military - Royal Netherlands East Indies Air Force
Summary: The plane went missing while en route from Merauke to Cairns. The last radio contact was 15 minutes before ETA.  A scientifiexpedition found the wreckage in January 1989, 65 km northwest from Cairns at a height of 1,200 meters.
Broke-up in flight either due to an explosion or catastrophistructural failure of the aircraft.

Airline/Op: Military - United States Army Air Force

Summary: Missing on an evacuation flight from Berlin to Munich.

Airline/Op: Eastern Air Lines / Military - U.S. Army Air Corps
Military - United States Army Air Force
Military - U.S. Navy / Military - U.S. Navy

Summary: Flew into the side of a hill.
Collided with Mt. Ptolemy while en route.
The aircraft lost its right wing and disintegrated over Donner Summit for reasons unknown.

Airline/Op: Military U.S. Navy / Military - U.S. Navy
Summary: Collided in midair while a fighter made practice diving maneuvers on the formation.
The two aircraft collided in midair, 20 miles north of the Panamanian island of Coiba while searching for a missing plane. Ten died aboard each aircraft.

Airline/Op: Military - Royal Netherlands Naval Air Service

Summary: Made a 360 degree turn and dove into the sea, 15 miles off Iwo Jima .
Poor weather at the destination airport forced the crew to divert to Rio de Janeiro. While approaching to land the aircraft flew into a mountain, 14 miles from the airport.
Turned the wrong way while attempting to land and slammed into a mountain, bursting into flames.

Airline/Op: British European Airways / Military - Soviet Air Force

Summary: Cargo flight. The in-flight failure of the fuselage carry-in structure beneath the fin, due to extreme turbulence.
A midair collision occurred between a SAS DC-6 and a Royal Air Force Avro York MW248. Thirty-two killed on the DC-6, seven on the York.  ATC error.
Cargo flight. The captain's action in undertaking simulated emergency procedures at a dangerously low altitude.
Lost contact with the aircraft after the crew reported passing Cape Spencer. The wreckage was never found.  Cause undetermined.

Radio contact was lost after the crew reported being 50 nm south of Miami. Departure from San Juan with known electrical problems and discharged batteries. Ditched in the Gulf of Mexico after it ran out of fuel. Offical cause unknown.

Lost at sea on a flight from Bermuda to Kingston, Jamaica. The last radio message reported the plane was crossing 30 degrees N.  Nothing further was heard from the plane. No wreckage was ever found. The weather was good at the time. The plane was named Star Ariel. Cause undetermined.
The aircraft, part of the 301st BG  15 AFW, cashed into mountains after encountering icing conditions.
Both the No. 1 and No. 2 propellers detached in flight which led to the crew ditching the plane close to shore.
The aircraft was part of relief efforts of the Ecuador earthquake.

Fuel exhaustion forced the plane to ditch in the AtlantiOcean, 15 km off the coast of Ireland. The plane stayed afloat for 15 minutes but 8 occupants died due to exposure or drowning. Failure of the captain to properly supervise the crew while en route.

While attempting for the third time to land at Santa Maria, the aircraft, flew into Redondo Mountain at 2,950 ft. on San Miguel Island. Crew error. Failure to carry out either of the two approach procedures adopted for Santa Maria airport. False position report give by crew. Inadequate navigation.  Failure to identify Santa Maria airport when flying in VFR conditions. French middleweight boxing champion Marcel Cerdan, 33, and French violinist, Ginette Neveu killed.

Airline/Op: Eastern Air Lines / Military - Bolivian Air Force

Summary: Hit a mountain and burned 30 miles north of  Karachi airport. Navigational error.
Flew into a mountain in the Pyrenees.
Flew into a mountain due to a navigational error.
Ditched in the ocean while on approach.

Airline/Op: Cubana de Aviacion / Military -  US Navy
Summary: The plane, on a flight from Miami to Cuba, collided with a US Navy Beechcraft at 4,000 feet. Thirty-nine killed on the DC-4, four killed on the Beechcraft.  Failure of both crews to maintain sufficient vigilance under VFR conditions to prevent a collision.
The aircraft, with the No. 4 propeller feathered, stalled and dived into San Francisco Bay. An inadvertent stall at a low altitude from which recovery was not effected.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S. Air Force / U.S. Air Force

Summary: A navigational error on the part of the captain. This error was severely aggravated by the lack of proper radio aids from the destination airport, the unserviceability of the aircraft R/T equipment, and to a lesser degree the physical condition of the crew. The secondary cause was the cargo plane coming into close proximity of high ground due to the captains uncertainty of his position.
Lost altitude and ditched near shore after taking off.
The plane trees and high ground while on approach. The flight's deviation from the established approach procedure.
Last know coordinates 46' 15' N, 46'31'W, over the North Atlantic. A distress message was received. No trace of the aircraft or its occupants were ever found.
The cargo plane flew into a mountain.
The cargo plane flew into a mountain at 8,000 ft.

The plane broke apart over the Susitna Valley of South Central Alaska and the scattered parts fell onto Kesugi Ridge, which is now within Denali State Park. Six servicemen wearing parachutes escaped by being thrown from the disintegrating aircraft.

Airline/Op: Soc. de Tr. Aériens d'Extrême Orient

Summary: The plane ditched into the AtlantiOcean after running out of fuel. Three non-swimming passengers drowned due to lack of lifesaving equipment aboard. Negligence of the crew in not monitoring the fuel situation as the flight progressed.
Flew into a mountain, 35 miles northeast of McGrath.
Hit Mt. Kilmanjaro while en route. Wreckage found after 10 months.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S. Air Force / Military - U.S. Air Force

Summary: Hit Caparao Mountain while en route, 1 hour after taking off.  Failure to follow flight plan.
The cargo plane ditched into the Thoa river. Fuel exhaustion.

Airline/Op: United Air Lines / Trans World Airlines

Summary: Midair collision. Both planes landed safely. Failure of both aircraft to observe and avoid the other aircraft.
While attempting to land the aircraft descended below the ILS glideslope and hit a tree. Using the lights of the airport the captain misjudged the height he was flying.
Hit El Rucio Mountain at 6,200 ft. which was obscured by clouds. Lack of cockpit discipline. Flight on instruments at an excessively low altitude for the route.
The stalling of the aircraft following a loss of airspeed, whereupon it unintentionally went into a spin. In view of insufficient altitude, it was not possible to level off the aircraft.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S.  Air Force / Military - U.S. Navy
Military - U.S. Marine Corps/Military - U.S. Marine Corps

Summary: While approaching Cairo, the aircraft was diverted to Port Said where it ditched into Menzalah Lake.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S. Air Force/Military - U.S. Air Force
United Air Lines / Military - U.S. Air Force
Capital Airlines / Military - Air National Guard
Military - U.S. Air Force / U.S. Air Force

Summary: The aircraft was missing on a flight from Cabo Ruivo to Funchal over the North Atlantiafter transmitting an emergency message positioning the aircraft at  36 degrees 40 minutes N 12 degrees W.
The crew failed to recognize and correct the development of excessive yaw which caused an unintentional rolling maneuver at an altitude too low to permit complete recovery.
The aircraft stalled for reasons undetermined, at an altitude too low to effect recovery.
Hit Mt. Capanne while en route.  Cause unknown.
The right wing of the cargo plane separated from the aircraft at 6,500 ft. Fatigue of the right wing lower attach angle bolts resulting in an in-flight wing failure.

Airline/Op: United Air Lines / Trans World Airlines

Summary: Five minutes after taking off from Lisbon, Portugal, the aircraft plunged into the AtlantiOcean. There were indications from the wreckage that the aircraft went into a spiral dive and hit the water at over 500 mph. Either through inattentiveness or loss of an artificial horizon or other instrument malfunction, the aircraft went into a steep left bank from which recovery was not possible. Attitude of the aircraft at the moment of impact pointed to over correction.
The cargo plane cashed while attempting to land. Shifting cargo.

Lost at sea while en route from Guam to the Philippines. The crew of the SS T.L. Lenzen supertanker sighted a midair explosion at 00:30 local time, from their position at 13 degrees 44' N, 134 degrees 49' E.  The subsequent search of over 144,000 square miles found nothing. Cause undetermined.
Nothing was heard from the aircraft after departing Bahia Solano. The wreckage was found 4 days later, 31 miles from the airport on Bonito Peak at an elevation of 2,400ft.

Airline/Op: Military - Union of Burma Air Force
Military - Japan Maritime Self Defense Force

Summary: Stuck a mountain in poor weather.

Following departure from Philadelphia, a high frequency whistling noise was heard and inspection revealed an escape of air at the lower aft corner of the rear service door. Pillow cases were placed in this area to reduce the air noise but no further action was taken. While the aircraft was descending through 4,000 feet the door blew out. The ensuing outward rush of air ejected a flight attendant who was near the door opening. Undetected insecure latching of the rear service door, resulting in an inflight explosive decompression which ejected a flight attendant from the aircraft.
Made a sharp turn, nosed up and hit the ground.
Twelve killed, including civilians. Two civilian houses burnt.

Airline/Op: Middle East Airlines / Military - Turkish Air ForceC-47
Military - Japan Air Self Defense Force

Summary: The aircraft flew into a mountain at 6,500 ft. Navigation error. Crew choose to fly a prohibited route at too low an altitude.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S. Air Force / Military -  U.S. Air Force
Summary: A mid-air collision occurred approximately 700 miles east of Miami, Florida.
During a stalling test the aircraft entered a stable stalled condition from which recovery was not possible.
Disapperared en route. Missing aircraft not recovered. Probable cause undetermined
While climbing to cruise altitude the plane hit turbulence, downdrafts and updrafts. One passenger's seat belt  failed, killing the passenger.
Instructed to land at Belgrade from the west, the aircraft was too low and off course when it hit Avala Hill, 600 ft. below the peak, exploding in flames.
Hit a mountain shortly after taking off exploding in flames.
After an improper climb, the aircraft flew into a 12,000 ft. mountain in the La Melosas area of the Andes. Crew did not follow flight plan for climbing out of Santiago.

Communication was lost with the aircraft soon after takeoff. Failure of corroded skin along the bottom center line of the aircraft which resulted in structural failure of the fuselage and aerial disintegration.
The plane was participating in U.S. - Canadian maneuvers.
The plane flew into a mountain after taking off from Beirut. Structural failure of the fuselage.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S. Army / Military - U.S. Army
Military - Japan Maritime Self Defense Force

Summary: Midair collision between a Douglas DC-3 and Piper PA-18.  Eighteen killed on the DC-3, one on the Piper.

Airline/Op: Trans World Airlines / Eastern Air Lines
Summary: Midair collision at 11,000 feet. Misjudgment of altitude separation by the crew of EAL 853 because of an optical illusion created by the up-slope effect of cloud tops resulting in an evasive maneuver by the EAL 853 crew and a reactionary evasive maneuver by  the TWA 42 crew. The 707 landed at JFK despite losing 25 feet of the left wing. There were no injuries to the crew of 7 and 51 passengers aboard the 707.  Three of the 46 passengers and 1 crew member aboard  EAL 853 were killed. Misjudgment of altitude separation by the crew of the Constellation because of an optical illusion created by the up-slope effect of cloud tops, resulting in an evasive maneuver by the Constellation crew and a reactionary evasive maneuver by the Boeing crew.
Airframe failure after flying into adverse weather. VFR flight into adverse weather conditions.
VFR flight into adverse weather conditions.

Airline/Op: Garuda  Indonesia Airlines / Garuda Indonesia Airlines

Summary: Collided with a Piper PA-23. Failure of both crews to maintain adequate lookout. One aboard the Piper killed.
The cargo plane cashed en route. Wreckage found three days later.
The cargo plane was never found.

The cargo  aircraft was not being flown at the recommended altitude when it reached mountains to be crossed, nor whas it at the proper crossing point. A secondary factor was the lack of navigational aids in the area.
Fatigue fracture on right wing leading to inflight separation in flight.
While attempting a go-around the plane hit Hong Kong mountain.

Airline/Op: Military - Japan Maritime Self Defense Force
Military - Republiof South Korea Air Force

Summary: The de Havilland and Piper collided while attempting to land at La Guardia Airport. The Piper did not reply to instructions from the tower and landed without clearance. Congested traffipattern. Inadequate spacing of traffiwere contributing factors. All three killed on the Piper.
An unintentional stall and incipient spin at a low altitude from which recovery was not possible.
Collided with a US Air Force Lockheed RF-4C Phantom II.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S. Marine Corps/Military - U.S. Marine Corps
Summary: A mid-air collision occurred between the two aircraft as they attempted to land at the New River Marine Corps Air Facility located on the grounds of Camp Le Jeune.
The aircraft was unable to maintain flying speed after taking off. Plane overloaded by 220 lbs.
The aircraft descended too low and flew into the southern slope of Black Down Hill.  Descended through its assigned altitude for reasons unknown. Actress June Thorburn, 36,  killed.
The plane flew into 10,500 ft. Carpish Mountain,30 miles from Tingo Maria.
Vanished without a trace over the Himalayas while en route.
Cruising at flight level 260, some type of emergency developed. An abrupt descent was begun and accelerated until aerodynamiforces broke apart the plane. Cause unknown.

The aircraft was believed to have gone into a spin or spiral dive with recovery at about 12,000 ft. The dive apparently caused structural damage which resulted in the aircraft plunging into St George's Channel, 10 miles east of Carnsore Point. Possible causal factors may have been metal fatigue, corrosion, flutter (vibration) or a bird strike.

Airline/Op: Military - U.S. Army / Military - U.S. Army
Summary: A mid-air collision occurred between the two helicopters at about 1,000 ft. altitude.

The plane's wing hit an obstruction, the plane cartwheeled and broke-up and burst into flames. The obstruction was a 45 gallon drum which had been placed about 7 feet high on a structure being used as a shower.

The helicopter suddenly descended to the ground with an erratiaction of the main rotor blades and burst into flames. A faulty main rotor blade damper caused one of the rotor blades to detach for reasons undetermined and strike the fuselage.
The aircraft flew into the side of Mt. Jaiskibel after turned in the wrong direction.
Midair collision. Ninety-six killed on the An-12, 24 on the IL-14.
A mid-air collision between three helicopters at 900 ft. (66-16202) (66-16592) (66-16601).
Passenger inadvertentlly opened air stair door in flight, safety chain failed and passenger fell out.
Ditched into the Mediterranean sea. Cause unknown.

Airline/Op: Far Aviation - Air Taxi / Speeds Flying - Air Taxi
Military - U.S. Air Force / Military -  U.S. Army
Summary: A mid-air collision between the fixed-wing aircraft and helicopter at the de Havilland C-7A prepared to land and the Boeing Vertol took off.

Broke up in severe turbulence at 11,500 feet. Failure of the right wing that was weakened by pre-existing fatigue cracks.  The turbulence was not forcast and not known to the flight crew.  Improper maintenance. Incorrect weather forcast.
Aircraft failed to maintain flying speed during initial climb. Center of gravity aft of limits. Possible misuse of flaps.
Encountered extreme turbulence and downdrafts while en route.
Inadvertent contact with the water during low-level flight over open ocean while searching for survivors.
The cargo plane went missing en route.
Collided with trees on approach. Improper IFR operation. Descended below minima for reasons unknown.
Vanished en route. A message was received from the aircraft stating they were experiencing a vibration but not declaring an emergency followed by 'crew go to oxygen.'
Hit 15,500 ft. Mt. Choquetanga. Cause unknown. All members of the Bolivian soccer team The Strongest, killed.
At a height of 3,000 ft., the aircraft suddenly nosed  into the sea, 3 minutes after taking off.
Hit a mountain at 1,350 ft. on initital approach. Minimum flying altitude 1,900 ft.  Improper IFR operation.
The aircraft suffered an airframe failure while en route. Fatigue fracture of wing attachment fitting bolts. FAA replacement time exceeded.

Airline/Op: Del Rio Flying Service - Air Taxi
Summary: Flew into mountain ridge obscured by clouds. Continued VFR flight into adverse weather conditions.
Descended below minimum approach altitude for unknown reasons.
Flew into high ground after being diverted to Da Nang in poor weather conditions.

Airline/Op: Military - Vietnamese Air Force / Military - U.S. Army

Summary: Ditched in the ocean. Mayday received. No trace of the plane ever found.
Cashed into a mountain 15 minutes after taking off in poor weather conditions.
Hit  a mountain after deviating from the prescribed course. Wreckage found 6 days later.

Airline/Op: Hughes Airwest  / Military - US Marine Air Corps
All Nippon Airways /  Japanese Air Force

Summary: A few seconds after taking off the airliner lost altitude and slammed into the tarmaexploding in flames.

Airline/Op: C and C Aviaiton - Air Taxi

Summary: Collided with wires/poles while attempting to land. Improper IFR operation. Descended below MDA.
Midair collision.  The DC-9 descended onto the Cessna. Two killed aboard the Cessna. The DC-9 landed with no one aboard injured. Inadequacy of ATC facilities and services in the terminal area.
Strayed off course and flew into a mountain.
Structural failure and separation of both wings due to a fatigue crack in the center wing section.
Hti wires above creek while surveying flood damage.
The plane ditched into the sea, 14 miles from Gran Canana Island.
Midair collision. Seventeen aboard the HK-134 and twenty-one aboard the HK-107 killed.

Airline/Op: Ansett Airlines of Papua New Guinea

Summary: Improperly loaded aircraft, weight and center of gravity.

Airline/Op: Delta Air Lines/ North Central Airlines
Red Carpet Flying Service - Air Taxi

Summary: The aircraft entered a spin and dove into the ground.

Airline/Op: Lineas Aereas de Espana/Spantax SA Transportes
Summary: Midair collision. Convair crew improperly assessed collision-course situation. Contributing factor was poor quality of radio transmissions. All sixty-eight aboard the DC-9 were killed while the Convair landed safely.
A preexisting crack in the lower wing spar cause the wing to separate in flight. Inadequate inspection and maintenance of aircraft.
The aircraft hit high ground during an approach, 32 kms from the airport.
Collided with trees while en route. Cancelled IFR en route. Continued VFR flight into adverse weather conditions.
After making a right turn, the aircraft plunged to earth from 1,500 ft.  Electrical failure of the compass and main gyro.
Flew into Mt. Gimie while en route.
Flew into a mountain while en route. Flying under VFR in IFR conditons.
The cargo plane hit a mountain en route.
A 16 month old child was asphyxiated by a seat belt while unattended.
Fifiteen journalists aboard for an Asian tour.

On a routine United Nations flight to Damascus, Syria, from Beirut, Lebanon, climbed eastward over the Lebanese highlands. Apparently painted by Syrian radar and subsequently as it neared the village of Diemas, the decision was made to launch several SAM missiles, one of which destroyed the aircraft.
Tried to fly through an obscure mountain pass, tried to turn around and hit the ground.
While en route, the cargo plane lost a wing and spiraled into the ground. Failure of the right wing in fight. Fatigue fracture. Inadequate maintenance and inspection.

Airline/Op: Orient Air System and Integrated Services

Summary: The aircraft impacted high ground during approach. The crew descended below a safe altitude due to a position error resulting from misinterpretation of Doppler and weather radar.
Flew into the side of a mountain in poor weather conditons.

Midair collision between a DHC-6 and a Cessna 150 at 2,200 feet while approaching Ontario Airport. Twelve aboard the Otter  and two aboard the Cessna killed. The failure of both flight crews to see the other aircraft in sufficient time to initiate evasive action. This was because of the position of the sun, the closure angle of the aircraft and the necessity of the Twin Otter's flight crew to acquire visual contact with radar reported traffidirectly ahead of them.
Descended into obscured mountain slope. Continued VFR flight into adverse weather.
Collided with mountain at 1,500 ft. while attempting to land. Misjudged altitude and clearance.
Hit an 11,620 ft. mountain in poor weather.
Continued VFR flight in to adverse weather.

Structural failure and in-flight separation of the right wing. Fatigue cracks attributed to stress due to design. These cracks became critical sooner than anticipated. The cracks remained undetected and became critical because the manufacturer's inspection program for the area was insufficiently.
Instead of turning on course the cargo plane continued straight and hit a mountain.

Midair collision at FL187.  ATC error. Fifty-two deaths on the Antonov, 38 on the Yak. Violation of separation rules. Contributing causes were insufficient visual alertness on the part of both crews and a lack of situation analysis based on air/ground radio communications.
Collided with a Cessna 185 while climbing to cruise. Failed to see and void other aircraft.
Collided with cable crane. Crane operator failed to park crane boom in stowed position.
Flew into a 4,200 ft. mountain at 1,200 ft.
Ditched into the ocean while on approach. Crew error. Sensory illusion.
Exceeded design stress limits of aircraft after experiencing airframe ice.
Continued VFR flight into adverse weather conditions.

Airline/Op: Military - Japan Maritime Self Defense Force

Summary: The aircraft, flying VFR, collided with a mountain in deteriorating weather condtions after being blown off course which went unnoticed because of lacking navigational equipment.
The helicopter experienced rotor failure. Undersized threads on anti-node bar.
The plane, on a positioning flight flew into a side of the mountain
Hit trees and burst into flames shortly after taking off.

The plane was transporting company employees when it hit Surveyor Mountain 7 minutes after taking off from Klamath Falls. The plane hit trees along the crest of a mountain ridge along the flight path. Crew error. The crew's decision to undertake a direct point-to-point high cruise speed flight at low altitude.
The aircraft hit a mountain at an altitude of 2,000 ft. during an approach in poor weather. Crew's misjudgement in selection of a low altitude flight profile and inadequate ATC assistance.
The aircraft was on finals when it suddenly turned right and descended in a right wing-down attitude, striking the ground and cartwheeling into trees.
Hit high ground at 2,700 ft. in poor weather while on approach.

Airline/Op: Military - Union of Burma Air Force

Summary: Hit by  a U.S. Marine Corps RH-53D Sea Stallion helicopter during a hostage rescue operation while on the ground.
Slamed into a mountain while on approach.

Airline/Op: F.R. de la Direccion General de Ados

Summary: The main rotor disk failed from a fatigue fracture while attempting to land.
The cargo plane flew into the ground while trying to avoid bad weather.
While cruising at FL 210, the pitch trim moved to the full nose-down position. Gravational forces from the resulting dive led to the break-up of the aircraft.
The aircraft experienced in-flight structural failure. Severe corrosion in belly of plane led to a pressure hull rupture and disintegration of the plane.
Midair collision with a Soviet Air Force TU-16. The only surviving passenger, a 20 year old woman was found in a forest 3 days later. Poor communication between civilian and military ATCs.
Midair collision with a military Mi-8 helicopter.
The aircraft entered an area of severe turbulence and a tornado which resulted in the separation of the right wing and in-flight break up.
Collided with trees on final approach. Improper IFR operation. Failed to follow approved procedures.

Airline/Op: Military - Republiof South Korea Air Force
Military - Republiof South Korea Air Force

Summary: Collided with trees on approach. Weather briefing recommended no VFR flight. VFR flight into IFR conditions.
Ground collision. Eleven killed on the LET and none on the Tupolev.
The plane ran out of fuel on the third approach in poor weather.

Airline/Op: Air Taxi - Basco Flying Service Inc.
Air Taxi - Custom Air Transport Inc.

Summary: The crew deviated from course while descending to land. Navigational error. ATC procedural error in not identifying the planes position.

Airline/Op: Military - Japan Maritime Self Defense Force
Air Taxi - Four Corners Aviation Inc.
Air Taxi - Northern Air Services Inc.

Summary: Collided with a Chinese Air Force aircraft while taxing.
A passenger committed suicide by opening the right rear door and jumping out at 3,500 ft.

Airline/Op: Military - Japan Maritime Self Defense Force

Summary: The cargo plane went missing in the PacifiOcean while en route.

Airline/Op: Air Taxi - Monument Valley Air Service
Empresa Nacional de Transp.  Trabalho Aereo

Summary: During a night arrival, the flight was on an instrument approach to the Gulkana Airport when radio contact with the aircraft was lost. Search was initiated & the wreckage was found 7.4 mi north of the terminal VORr on the 330 deg radial.  Improper IFR procedure. Minimum descent altitude not maintained.

The aircraft hit a mountain while on approach in level flight at an altitude of 2,400 feet. Navigational error by the crew resulting from their use of the incorrect navigational facility and their failure to adequately monitor the flight instruments. Improper IFR procedure. Lack of proper radio equipment. Playwright, Larry Shue, 39, killed.
Lost power and spiraled into the ground after takeoff. Contaminated fuel. Overloaded.

Detonation of a explosive device in the passenger compartment causing four passengers to be sucked out.  The plane landed safely at Athens. The plastiexplosive was left under a seat by a woman carrying a Lebanese passport.
Lost a wing in heavy turbulence at low altitude.
Detonation of an explosive device in the rear section of the cabin while on the ground and passengers were boarding. The aircraft was named City of Colombo.
Flew into the side of a mountain in poor weather.

Midair collision. Inadequate visual lookout on the part of  both aircraft. Twenty killed on the de Havilland and  five on the Helitech. The failure of the flightcrew of both aircraft to see and avoid each other for undetermined reasons.
Shiraz Airport was attacked by Iraqi aircraft. Passengers were deplaning at the time of the attack.

Airline/Op: Air Taxi - New London Flying Services Inc.

Summary: Ditched into the sea in poor weather conditions.
Stalled and went into a spin during a low-level refueling practice. The stall was propagated by the wake of a B-52.
The air ambulance impacted a mountain at 8,000 ft. while circling to land. Improper planned approach. Improper altitude maintained. Inadequate preflight planning. Approach charts inaccurate.

The cargo plane lost the left wing while in a holding pattern. The left wing failed under normal flight loads as a result of a fatigue crack in the center section lower wing skin. Anomalies in the radiographs taken during mandatory non-destructive testing inspections were not correctly interpreted.

Airline/Op: Air Taxi - Flying School of the Cascades Inc.

Summary: As the aircraft turned inbound to intercept the localizer it collided with a mountain, 12 miles ESE of the airport. Improper IFR procedures. Improper use of navigation receiver.
The cargo flight crew decided on a visual approach, ignored the GPWS warning and flew into a mountain.

Airline/Op: Air Taxi - Northern Arizona Aircraft Inc.
Military - Russian Air Force / Military - Russian Air Force

Summary: After gaining altitude the cargo plane descended until it impacted trees. Improper IFR procedure by the first officer during takeoff, his lack of instrument scan, his failure to maintain a positive rate of climb or to identify the resultant descent, and the captain's inadequate supervision of the flight. Contributing factors were: dark night, low ceiling, drizzle, the first officer's lack of total experience in the type of operation, and possible spatial disorientation of the first officer.
The plane went missing en route.

The airliner hit a mountain while attempting to land at Santa Maria. The crew mistakenly continued to descend through 3,000 ft. which it was clear to. Because of a overlap in communications, the tower did not notice the mistake. The aircraft continued to descend and did not comment or react to warnings from the GPSW for 7 seconds. The aircraft then hit Pico Alto mountain at an altitude of 2,000 ft.  Procedural errors by the flight crew and ATC. Descent of the aircraft below minimum sector altitude. Transmission from the tower of a QNH value higher than the actual value.
The cargo plane descended below minimums and impacted trees and a hill. Non-standard phraseology used by Kuala Lumpur ATC, causing the crew to misinterpret the instructions.

Airline/Op: Air Taxi - Las Vegas Flyers Inc.

Summary: Hit high ground 27 km from the airport.
A dry  fuel pump led to the ignition of fuel vapors.
The plane hit a 7,000 ft, mountain 10 minutes after taking off. The flight crew used an incorrect departure procedure.

Airline/Op: Military - People's Army/ Military - Peoples Air Force

Summary: Midair collision. Five killed on ZA-DAX, ZK-DQF landed safely.
Suddenly dove into a field as it prepared to land at Likouala.
While on VOR approach the aircraft flew into the ground.

There was an explosion in the center fuel tank while the aircraft was being pushed back for flight. Ignition of vapors in the empty center tank probably resulted from faulty wiring. Several causes have been presumed including chafed insulation on the wiring for the center fuel tank float level switch and damaged insulation on the wiring of the nearby wing anti-ice valve.

In-flight loss of the left horizontal stabilizer. Forty-seven screw fasteners that would have attached the upper surface of the leading edge assembly for the left side of the horizontal stabilizer were missing. Lack of compliance with FAA approved maintenance procedures.
The plane was not able to land at Sampit due to smoke and haze.  The plane held for 3 hours waiting for an improvement after which contact was lost.  The plane was never found.
Flew into the side of a hill towards the end of the flight while flying VOR.  The crew flew along the wrong valley.
A passenger died of cholera while en route.

While en route, the aircraft cashed into trees and burst into flames.
After climbing to a height of 800 ft. the plane dove into the ground. Improper loading and overloaded.
The rotor blades hit an oil rig in the Arabian Sea.

The slats were inadvertently deployed while at FL 330. The aircraft progressed through several pitch oscillations and lost 5,000 feet in altitude. Inadequate design of the flap/slat actuation handle that allowed the handle to be easily and inadvertently dislodged from the UP/RET position, thereby causing extension of the leading edge slats during cruise flight.
Flew into hillside in poor weather conditions.
The cargo plane impacted a hill while on visual approach to El Yopal.
On final approach at low speed the left wing dropped and touched the ground during a stall or deliberate low left turn. The plane cartwheeled and broke up.

Midair collision at 39,000 ft. The Tupolev 154 aircraft was flying at the wrong cruise altitude which caused the midair collision. Twenty-four killed aboard the Tupolev and 9 aboard the C-141. Contributing factors included weak flight-following procedures of the Luanda ATC and  poor regional ground communications.

Two hours into the flight, at FL 310, the plane received reports of severe clear air turbulence in the area and the seat belt sign was turned on. Moments later, the aircraft suddenly dropped around one hundred feet seriously injuring many passengers and causing damage to the aircraft. The plane landed safely back at Tokyo, but  one passenger died of her injuries.

Summary: The plane was en-route from Barcelona, Spain to Oran, Algeria, 80 miles off the coast of Valencia, Spain when it informed Valencia ATC it was going to change course in order to avoid bad weather. There was no further contact with the aircraft. Debris was sighted two days later on the water.

The plane was being used by the Penitentiary and Prison National Institute, Inpec, to fly prisoners from Medellín to Popayán. The aircraft had just finished flying 50 prisoners to Popayán when it took off from Popayán to pick up more prisoners. The aircraft nosed into the ground shortly after becoming airborne.
The plane tookoff and encountered heavy clouds all along the route.  Wreckage was found 42 miles from Oiapoque, in an Amazon forest. Poor weather conditions.
